{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3532014,"name":"Tommy","username":"HandsomeBoulder","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/handsomeboulder/{size}/254279_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T22:32:52.520Z","cooked":"

(Programmer talking through another account, waiting on mine to be confirmed)

Having some trouble writing our first swerve drive. Trying to use the YAGSL-Example repository with our configurations dropped in. The robot has trouble translating in the Y axis and rotating. X translation works fine but any movement which causes angle motor movement causes everything to freak out (see attached video.) In addition, if we restart with anything other than Y translation, our module’s encoder offsets seem to be off and sometimes need to be recalculated.

Software:

  • YAGSL
  • Repository
    Hardware:
  • MK4n (L2 Gear Ratio)
  • Kraken X60
  • CANcoder
  • NavX2
  • 40A Drive Current & 30A Angle Current

Using some basic test code I assume that the issue is not mechanical or electrical at slow speeds, higher speeds were not tested.

Our season’s main codebase was able to run in the simulator and was capable of XY movement and rotation without issue (there was some issues with pose twitching which I attributed to poor simulation estimation, but could’ve indicated something else that I don’t know). However when I plugged in configuration values it did not work.

I’ve tried recreating configurations and setting all CAN devices to factory defaults to no avail. I did find some configuration issues which fixed some other issues but as of now there seem to be no configuration mistakes.

Just trying to get a basic drive going, don’t need anything related to auton or anything else yet. Let me know if anyone needs anything (pictures, video, random numbers, etc.) as I’m not too sure where to even start with providing additional information.

The module location entries need to be fixed.
Front values are 1/2 drive base length
Left values are 1/2 track width.
Signs are based on module locations with robot center on XY origin,
Check some of the other folders you have for examples.

Are module locations based on robot center or gyro center? Our current robot has the gyroscope off a bit from the center due to physical constraints (see picture). We’re going to make sure its centered when we build our final chassis.

Nonetheless, we’ve tried configurations both with robot center and gyro center if I remember correctly, however I could test again later.

Also I’m not too sure what you mean by “signs are based on module locations.” If you’re referring to negating values based on which module (e.g. +X+Y for front left and -X-Y for back left), then from what I see it’s correct.

Okay, good to know.
Angle motor encoders were CCW negative so I inverted them. Any particular reason why they should be different or is it just because I never really told that information?

Angle motors or absolute encoders? Or both? The reason the modules are spinning out of control is bc the motor and encoders are out of phase. So when one goes up the other goes down

The YAGSL code you linked was using the swerve/5183 folder.
The position values there are
Front Left “front”: 16.75, “left”: 14
Front Right “front”: 16.75, “left”: -7.75
Back Left “front”: -10.5, “left”: 14
Back Right “front”: -10.5, “left”: -7.75
The signs are correct but the values don’t look right.

Only the encoders on the angle motors are inverted, not the absolute encoder, so that could be the problem. What’s the fix? Just make them both not inverted?

Alright… it works! Driving works normal but there’s still a couple of issues.

The absolute encoders seem to drift after a bit, where they won’t be exactly where they want to be and it gets worse the more I drive.

Secondly, I have to make sure each module is at 0 before I turn it on, which I think is also due to the above issue in some capacity

I don’t own the thread, so I can’t mark solutions… oh well. It was really a mix of every solution above.

To fix the swerve drift we found from a CTA at our first competition that the encoder magnets in the modules need to be fixed with glue or locktite. After doing that, we never had any drift issues.
